Award.AwardTitle: Small-Business ERC Collaborative Opportunity Package Prototyping of the Environment Resistant Package (ERP) with commercial Inertial Sensor and Oscillator Companies

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

This Small-Business/ ERC Collaborative Opportunity (SECO) grant will help ePack, Inc., commercialize the Environmental Resistant Package (ERP), which is a platform technology developed in the Wireless Integrated Microsystems (WIMS) Engineering Research Center (ERC). Microsensors (as well as many other electronic components) are fragile and sensitive to particles moisture, vibration, shock and temperature changes in the environment. Packaging therefore is a key factor for protecting these device in real world applications and therefore for their commercialization. In fact, packaging is one of the biggest limiting factors for the commercialization of new microelectromechanical systems (MEMS).

This is why ePack was founded and then fully spun out of the WIMS-ERC at the University of Michigan (U of M) in 2010 and has an exclusive license for the patent on the ERP technology. The ERP technology enables vacuum packaging, vibration isolation and low power oven control of devices. The purpose of this SECO grant is to prototype commercial inertial sensors and oscillators in the ERP in order to demonstrate 10 / 100 times improved vibration resistance or temperature stability (and therefore that level of improved performance) in several different application areas.

Broader Impact (Applications of the Technology)
This will enable a next generation of cost efficient, high performance and high reliability applications including: handheld navigation systems for firefighters and troops; navigation of unmanned air vehicles for police, military and commercial applications; motion control for industrial robots; and mobile broadband for commercial trucks and small jets.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Micromachined sensors and other small scale devices have many high volume, low unit cost (<$1) applications. For higher performance, high reliability, and harsh environments, these devices require vibration isolation, temperature control, and/or a vacuum environment during operation. This either precludes their use or requires expensive ($10 to $3000), power hungry (>1 W) and large size (1 - 1000 cm3) packaging in order to realize sufficient performance and measurement stability. This acts as a barrier to entry for many applications.

The environment resistant package (ERP), was developed by in order to address this problem. This enables a ×10-100 reduction in size, power and/or price for a wide range of high performance sensors and applications. It consists of a micromachined platform which is mechanically and enables precison temperature corrections for the device. This is important because even small temperature changes and outside vibration can drastically reduce the performance of many types of precision sensors. The ERP isolation platform can also provide vibration filtering and stress isolation for mechanical isolation. In this way, the ERP can convert a low performance (very temperature or vibration sensitive device) into a very high performance environmentally insensitive device.

In this work ePack applied the ERP packaging technology and demonstrated that it could take lower performing "consumer grade" devices and improve their performance so they can be used for "industrial grade" commercial or even "tactical grade" military applications while keeping it small, low power and low cost. Based off of this work, ePack received an NSF PII SBIR to develop industrial grade sensor products. 


Last Modified: 01/13/2015
Modified by: Jay S Mitchell
